intro: Laphamia laciniata, commonly known as the narrow-leaved lophotus, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and umbel-like inflorescences. The plant typically grows in rocky, arid environments and has adapted to thrive in low-nutrient soils. Its leaves are narrow and deeply lobed, giving it a distinctive appearance. The flowers are small and white, often arranged in clusters, contributing to its ornamental value in dry gardens.
